    Inhibition of Rhodesain as a Novel Therapeutic Modality for Human African Trypanosomiasis

    • Roberta Ettari*†

    Abstract

    Rhodesain, a cathepsin L-like cysteine protease of T. brucei rhodesiense, is considered a potential target for the treatment of human African trypanosomiasis. Recent findings have confirmed that rhodesain, a lysosomal protease, is essential for parasite survival. Rhodesain is required by T. brucei to cross the blood–brain barrier, degrade host immunoglobulins, and turn over variant surface coat glycoproteins of T. brucei, which impair effective host immune responses. In this Perspective, we discuss the main classes of rhodesain inhibitors, including peptidic, peptidomimetic, and nonpeptidic structures, emphasizing those that have exhibited an optimal match between enzymatic affinity and trypanocidal profile and those for which preclinical investigations are currently in progress.

    1 Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT or sleeping sickness) is an endemic parasitic disease of sub-Saharan Africa that is caused by two subspecies of protozoa belonging to the genus Trypanosoma: T. brucei gambiense and T. brucei rhodesiense.(1) This vector-borne disease, which is transmitted by the bite of tsetse fly (genus Glossina), exhibits a high index of infectivity; the estimated number of actual cases is currently 30 000.(2)
    T. b. gambiense, which is responsible for more than 95% of HAT cases, is widespread in central and western Africa and causes a slower-developing, chronic form of the disease. T. b. rhodesiense is the most common subspecies in southern and eastern Africa and causes a rapid-onset, acute form of trypanosomiasis.(3) Although not as widespread as T. b. gambiense, the relatively rapid disease progression after T. b. rhodesiense infection results in a higher mortality rate.
    Both parasitic subspecies produce two main symptomatic stages of HAT. Stage 1 (the early or hemolymphatic stage) initiates soon after the tsetse fly bite and can last several weeks or months (depending on the specific subspecies). During this stage, the parasite initially lives within the bloodstream and subsequently migrates to other areas of the human host, such as the lymph nodes, spleen, and spinal fluid, causing malaria-like symptoms (rash, fever, shaking chills, muscle aches, and fatigue). Left untreated, stage 1 of HAT evolves to stage 2 (the late or neurological stage), during which the parasite invades the brain, causing progressive mental deterioration, sleep disturbances (from which the disease gets its common name), coma, and eventually death.(4)
    The development of a preventive vaccine would be an ideal approach to this devastating disease, but unfortunately, trypanosomes are able to evade the host immune system because of the high degree of antigenic variation expressed by the glycoprotein forming their surface coat.(5, 6) Therefore, chemotherapy remains the only viable strategy for the treatment and control of the infection. The current chemotherapy for HAT includes only four drugs. Three of these drugs, suramin (1), pentamidine (2), and melarsoprol (3) (Figure 1), were developed over 60 years ago and exhibit severe side effects. Compound 3, a trivalent arsenical, is the most toxic and causes reactive encephalopathy in 5–10% of treated patients, with 1–5% mortality.(7) Moreover, the efficacy of these drugs is limited by parasite resistance, lack of broad-spectrum activity, and parasite stage-specific activity: 1 (a polyanionic sulfated naphthylamine) and 2 (an aromatic diamidine) are effective only in the early stage of the disease, and the latter is active only against T. b. gambiense; 3 and eflornithine (4) (a selective inhibitor of ornithine decarboxylase, 1990, Figure 1) are effective during the late stage of the disease, with 4 exhibiting activity only against T. b. gambiense.(8, 9) Chemotherapy with 4 is safer compared to the other drug treatments, although its mode of action is trypanostatic rather than trypanocidal.(10) Nifurtimox (5, Figure 1), a 5-nitrofuran derivative with antifungal properties that is licensed for use only in Argentina and Germany, is another effective compound that was first used for the treatment of Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis, which is caused by T. cruzi).(11) Unlike other trypanocidal drugs, which are administered by injection, 5 is orally bioavailable. Combination therapy of 5 with other drugs, particularly 4, is recommended as a first-line treatment for stage 2 HAT caused by T. b. gambiense or as an option for melarsoprol-refractory stage 2 HAT caused by T. b. rhodesiense.(12) Another trypanocidal agent that is active against the first stage of HAT and is orally bioavailable is pafuramidine (6, DB289) (Figure 2),(13) which is an experimental prodrug that is converted in vivo into furamidine (7, DB75) (Figure 2). Although it was used in phase III clinical trials in 2007, its use was halted in 2008 because of hepatic toxicity.(14)
    More recently, novel boron-containing molecules have been identified, among which 4-fluoro-N-(1-hydroxy-1,3-dihydrobenzo[c][1,2]oxaborol-6-yl)-2-(trifluoromethyl)benzamide (8, SCYX-7158) (Figure 3) emerged as an orally active drug candidate that completed preclinical studies in 2011. Compound 8 was able to cure, both in the blood and in the brain, mice infected with T. brucei.(15) The mechanism by which 8 behaves as a trypanocidal agent is currently unknown. The benzoxaborole 8 entered phase I clinical trials in France in 2012 to evaluate its safety and tolerability for the treatment of both stage 1 and stage 2 HAT.
    The present scenario clearly indicates that new drugs with an acceptable efficacy and safety profile are urgently required and that new trypanosomal targets must be identified and explored for new therapeutic opportunities.
    Enzymes, proteins, or metabolic pathways that are unique to parasites and absent or significantly divergent in the mammalian hosts are commonly regarded as ideal targets. A typical example is trypanothione, an unusual form of glutathione that is unique to tripanosomatids.(16) In addition, the glycolytic pathway is regarded as an excellent target because of the unusual compartmentalization of the glycolytic enzymes within peroxisome-like organelles known as glycosomes.(17) Similarly, enzymes that are required for parasite survival but are not essential in human cells because of the presence of alternative metabolic pathways can be regarded as potential therapeutic targets.(18)
    Recently, de Koning et al., through the pharmacological validation of T. brucei phosphodiesterases,(19) proposed a diametrically opposing point of view that parasitic enzymes with highly conserved human homologues might represent a promising reservoir of new potential drug targets. The authors proposed that the pre-existing expertise and technology developed for human enzymes could rapidly bridge the gap between the urgent medical need for new antiparasitic drugs and the technological and financial obstacles associated with their development. Issues concerning parasite versus host specificity could be addressed by exploiting parasite-specific structural features.(19) Interestingly, Wyatt et al. recently reported that N-myristoyltransferase (NMT) inhibitors, despite their minimal in vitro selectivity between TbNMT and mammalian NMT, are well tolerated at efficacious doses, likely due to selectivity at the cellular level.(20)
    In this context, cysteine proteases of the papain superfamily, which are ubiquitously expressed in both protozoans and humans and have been successfully targeted to treat several human diseases, have been recognized as valuable targets for the treatment of parasitic diseases.(21) The key role that cysteine proteases play in parasitic infection, coupled with the relative lack of redundancy in mammalian systems, has highlighted parasitic proteases as attractive targets for the development of new chemotherapeutic agents. The evaluation of cysteine protease inhibitors in experimental models of parasitic diseases has served as an important “proof of concept” and confirmed their in vivo applicability. Examples of the chemical and genetic validation of cysteine proteases as drug targets have been reported for both T. cruzi and Leishmania.(21)
    The cysteine protease activity of T. brucei has been validated as a drug target based on the observation that Z-Phe-Ala-CHN2 (9a), a diazomethyl ketone inhibitor, kills parasites both in vitro and in vivo.(22) In addition, through the use of biotinylated cysteine protease inhibitors, Troeberg et al. concluded that the observed trypanocidal activity on the cultured bloodstream form of T. b. brucei was likely attributable to the irreversible binding of the inhibitors to trypanopain-Tb.(22)
    The major cysteine protease expressed by T. brucei is cathepsin L (TbCatL), which is commonly known as rhodesain and was initially referred to as trypanopain-Tb. Cathepsin B (TbCatB) represents a minor but essential protease. The role and relevance of these two enzymes are controversial. RNA interference studies conducted by Mackey et al.(23) and Abdulla et al.(24) demonstrated that the elimination of TbCatB cured mice of trypanosomal infection, whereas TbCatL suppression only prolonged the lifespan of the infected mice and primarily prevented the parasites from reaching the central nervous system (CNS), where they give rise to the second and most severe stage of sleeping sickness. A recent study by Steverding et al.(25) argued that a rigorous interpretation of the relative contributions of TbCatB and TbCatL to the survival of T. brucei could not be based on these data because these experiments never resulted in complete silencing of TbCatL. Notably, by using a number of peptidyl inhibitors, Steverding et al. presented new data suggesting that TbCatL, rather than TbCatB, is the essential cysteine protease of T. brucei and should be considered the primary target for HAT treatment.
    In the past few decades, many chemotypes have been identified as rhodesain (TbCatL) inhibitors, including peptides, peptidomimetics, and non-peptide small molecules that are able to interact with the enzyme in a reversible or irreversible manner. Many of these inhibitors were not originally designed as rhodesain inhibitors but as potential ligands for several disease-associated cysteine proteases, such as human cathepsins B, L, and S, cruzain, and falcipain. Crystal structures of rhodesain in complex with specific inhibitors have provided new insights(26, 27) that have enabled the design of specific rhodesain inhibitors based on structures or scaffolds that are suitable for drug development, thus expediting the development of potential agents for the treatment of HAT.

    2 Rhodesain Structure and Functions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Rhodesain (TbCatL) is a clan CA, family C1 (papain-family) cathepsin L-like cysteine protease that plays many essential roles in all phases of the T. b. rhodesiense life cycle.(27) It consists of a single polypeptide chain of 215 amino acids, which adopts the classic papain-like fold: the protease is divided into a left (L) and right (R) domains (Figure 4) with the catalytic triad (Cys25/His162/Asn182) located in a cleft between the two domains.
    For all cysteine proteases, the catalytic mechanism requires the conversion of the weakly nucleophilic thiol group of the Cys25 residue to a highly nucleophilic thiolate ion, which involves the other two residues of the catalytic triad. The Asn182 residue, which acts as a H-bond acceptor, is responsible for the stabilization of the correct tautomeric form of the His162 imidazole ring, which acts as a base and has been implicated in the deprotonation of the Cys25 thiol group. The next step is the nucleophilic attack of the Cys– group on the carbonyl carbon of the scissile amide bond. Subsequent rearrangements involving other amino acid residues within the active site permit peptide bond hydrolysis and the regeneration of the free enzyme.
    The substrate specificity of cysteine proteases is governed by the nature of the amino acid residues surrounding the cleavage site. The nomenclature used for defining the binding pockets and the selectivity of the proteases is relative to the site of cleavage (scissile bond).(28) Sn represents the enzyme subsites (pockets) and is numbered S1–Sn toward the N-terminus of the substrate (nonprimed sites) and S1′–Sn′ toward the C-terminus (primed sites), beginning from the sites on each side of the scissile bond. Accordingly, the substrate residues that they accommodate are numbered P1–Pn, and P1′–Pn′, respectively. Hydrolysis occurs at the scissile bond between P1 and P1′.
    Two different crystal structures of rhodesain in complex with peptidyl vinyl sulfone inhibitors (PDB codes 2P7U(26) and 2P86(27)) have been reported, which will be discussed in further detail in a subsequent section. The T. b. brucei homologue brucipain is approximately identical to rhodesain (98.4% homology). Moreover, rhodesain possesses significant structural similarity to cruzain, the orthologous cysteine protease of T. cruzi, and slightly lower similarity with Plasmodium protease structures (e.g., to falcipain-2 (FP-2) or falcipain-3 (FP-3)).
    Rhodesain is required for the parasite to cross the blood–brain barrier (BBB) of the human host and cause the late (and lethal) stage of the disease.(29) In vitro studies in human brain microvascular endothelial cells have demonstrated that rhodesain facilitates the parasitic crossover through the BBB by activating Gq-protein-coupled receptors known as protease activated receptors (PARs), which might play a role in calcium signaling pathways. Increased intracellular calcium levels ultimately lead to cytoskeletal changes in endothelial cells and BBB dysfunction.(30, 31)
    Rhodesain is also involved in the turnover of variant surface glycoproteins (VSGs) of trypanosomes.(6, 32) VSGs form a densely packed coat surrounding the parasites that enables infecting T. brucei populations to persistently evade host immune responses, enabling chronic infection. This protective action against the host’s immune system is ensured by two properties: a shielding mechanism and periodic antigenic variation. The dense nature of the VSG coat prevents the immune system of the mammalian host from accessing the plasma membrane or any other invariant surface epitope. At the C-terminus, the VSGs are anchored to the lipid bilayer of the parasite membrane via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor. The linkage of the VSG–GPI anchor occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum, and truncated VSGs, which lack the additional C-terminal GPI signals, remain unprocessed within the endoplasmic reticulum. The unprocessed VSGs are then directed to the lysosomes and eventually degraded.(33) A growing body of evidence indicates that rhodesain is the predominant lysosomal protease.(34)
    Other studies examining congopain, a cathepsin L-like cysteine protease isolated from one of the causative agents of nagana (animal African trypanosomiasis) in cattle (T. congolense), have suggested that the orthologous enzyme of rhodesain plays a key role in the degradation of VSGs within the lysosome(35) and have hypothesized that an extracellular activity of such a hydrolase might be involved in the degradation of host immunoglobulins.(35)

    3 Rhodesain Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this section, we provide an overview of the main classes of rhodesain inhibitors, which are grouped, based on their chemical structures, into peptidyl, peptidomimetic, and nonpeptidyl inhibitors. The members of each group can be further classified according to their modes of action. Reversible inhibitors usually bind to the enzyme via noncovalent interactions, although exceptions are known in which covalently bound inhibitors result in reversible inhibition due to hydrolytically labile bonding (e.g., peptidyl aldehydes). Reversible inhibitors can act in a competitive or noncompetitive manner. Competitive inhibitors compete with the substrate for access to the active site of the enzyme and can be displaced by increasing substrate concentrations. In contrast, in the case of noncompetitive inhibitors, the substrate and inhibitor bind independently to the enzyme. The inhibitor promotes a conformational change within the catalytic site that does not prevent the binding of the substrate but that promotes the formation of a nonproductive complex [E·S·I].
    Irreversible inhibitors bind covalently to the enzyme, resulting in the permanent inactivation of the target protease. Consequently, these inhibitors cannot be displaced by increasing the substrate concentration.
    For reversible inhibitors, IC50 values are typically used to describe inhibitory potency. However, for irreversible inhibitors, IC50 values are dependent on both the substrate concentration and the duration of the incubation of enzyme with inhibitor prior to the addition of substrate.(36) Thus, irreversible inhibitors should be described by the following kinetic parameters: (i) the dissociation constant (Ki) of the noncovalent enzyme–inhibitor complex [E·I], which is a measure of the binding affinity; (ii) the inactivation rate constant, also called the first-order rate constant of inhibition (kinac, min–1), which describes the rate of formation of the covalent enzyme–inhibitor complex E–I; (iii) the second-order rate constant of inhibition (k2nd, M–1 min–1), which is calculated from the kinac/Ki ratio, as a measure of inhibitor potency.

    3.1 Peptide-Based Rhodesain Inhibitors

    The peptide inhibitors described in the subsequent sections are typically characterized by the following common structural themes: (i) a peptide segment for recognition by the enzyme and (ii) an electrophilic moiety, which is usually referred to as a “warhead”, that can undergo nucleophilic attack of the cysteine residue of the active site. Thus, members of this group are all covalent inhibitors that usually inactivate the enzyme in an irreversible manner unless the covalent bond formed is hydrolytically labile, resulting in a reversible inhibition. The simplest example of a cathepsin L inhibitor is the diazomethylketone Z-Phe-Ala-CHN2 (9a), but this molecule is not selective for this type of cysteine protease.
    Notably, to avoid uncontrolled reactivity with nontarget proteins and physiologically relevant thiol-containing peptides (e.g., glutathione), the intrinsic reactivity of the electrophilic warhead on the inhibitor must be sufficiently low that reaction with Cys– occurs only after a specific, noncovalent binding that positions the reactive group at a distance and orientation that are favorable for the reaction.
    Moreover, considering the high degree of homology among cysteine proteases, efforts have focused on the development of papain L-like selective inhibitors that are able to discriminate between parasitic and mammalian proteases by exploiting the few differences in the amino acid residues surrounding the cleavage site within the catalytic pocket.

    3.1.1 Peptidyl Aldehyde and Ketone Derivatives

    Typical examples of electrophilic moieties that can be exploited as warheads for the design of cysteine protease inhibitors are aldehydes, which are known to form reversible complexes with cysteine proteases, and ketone derivatives such as chloromethyl, fluoromethyl, and diazomethyl ketones, which form irreversible covalent bonds with the thiolate anion.
    Several methyl ketone derivatives (9) that were tested against cultured T. b. brucei exhibited micromolar IC50 values (Table 01) and inhibited purified trypanopain-Tb with second-order rate constants of inhibition (k2nd) values in the 107 M–1 min–1 range.(22)

    In a recent study, two peptidyl aldehydes, Z-Phe-Tyr-CHO (10a) and 1-NapSO2-Ile-Trp-CHO (10b), and one diazomethyl ketone, Z-Phe-Tyr-(OtBu)-CHN2 (10c), that were previously reported to be potent human cathepsin L inhibitors(37) were evaluated for their inhibitory properties against recombinant rhodesain and compared to that of the model compound 9a.(22) The presence of a Tyr or Trp at the P1 position was proposed to be responsible for the increased inhibitory activity against cathepsin L compared to other cysteine proteases. These compounds displayed high k2nd values; in particular, 10a displayed impressive potency (k2nd = 1.38 × 108 M–1 min–1).(37)
    Inhibitors 10a and 10b also exhibited dose-dependent inhibition of trypanosome proliferation in the blood, with ED50 values in the nanomolar range and a high selectivity index in HL-60 cells. The optimal profile was exhibited by dipeptide 10b, with ED50 = 18 nM and selectivity index SI = 1150 (see Table 2), values that are comparable to those of suramine (ED50 = 130–360 nM, SI = 1900).(38) Interestingly, this molecule contains a naphthyl group at the P3 position, which has been suggested to promote penetration into the parasite(39) and might be responsible for the discrepancies between the enzyme inhibitory and trypanocidal activities of 10a and 10b.

    Notably, all of the inhibitors block lysosome-mediated proteolysis by inhibiting the brucipain enzyme of T. b. brucei.

    3.1.2 Michael Acceptor-Based Peptidyl Inhibitors

    One of the best-characterized classes of cysteine protease peptidic inhibitors is that containing the vinyl sulfone (VS) moiety. These proteases are widely employed as irreversible inhibitors because of their ability to form covalent bonds with the active site Cys residue, thus behaving as Michael acceptors.(40)
    The active site Cys residue undergoes a 1,4-Michael addition reaction, producing a permanently alkylated form of the enzyme. The oxygen atoms of the sulfone are involved in the hydrogen bonds with the enzyme active site, further increasing the electrophilic character of the vinyl β-carbon, which undergoes nucleophilic attack by the Cys– anion that is present within the active site.
    Rhodesain specificity at the S1′ site has been explored(34) by comparing the activity of vinyl sulfones bearing different substituents at P1′ (Table 3). The following activity trend emerged: OPh (11a) > CH2Ph (11b) > Ph (11c). Moreover, reduced activity was observed with the introduction of larger spacers (i.e., CH2CH2Ph, 11d) or with a sulfonamide moiety (i.e., NHPh, 11e).
    Table 3. Effect of the P1′ Substituent: Activity Trends of Vinyl Sulfonates, Vinyl Sulfones, and Vinyl Sulfonamides of the General Structure Cbz-Phe-HPhe-SO2R
    compdk2nd (M–1 min–1)
    11a3.48 × 108
    11b5.35 × 107
    11c1.61 × 107
    11d1.09 × 107
    11e2.24 × 106
    Crystal structures of rhodesain in complex with the peptide-based vinyl sulfones N-Mpip-Phe-HPhe-SO2Ph (12a, K11777) and Mu-Phe-HPhe-SO2Ph (12b, K11002) (Figure 5) have been reported (PDB codes 2P7U(26) and 2P86(27)). An interesting structural feature observed in the rhodesain–12b complex is the dual conformation of the P1′ phenyl substituent of the vinyl sulfone moiety, which results from its tendency to flip out of the S1′ pocket.
    In all papain-like cysteine proteases, the S2 site (Figure 6) defines the primary specificity toward peptidyl substrates. Rhodesain is generally able to tolerate a range of bulky hydrophobic residues within the S2 pocket(41, 42) and exhibits identical preferences for leucine and phenylalanine, in contrast to cruzain, which prefers phenylalanine.(34) The Leu67 residue of the S2 site perfectly accepts the bulky phenylalanine of 12b into the S2 hydrophobic environment, whereas the Ala208 residue at the bottom of the S2 site renders the pocket shallower, while the Gln159 and Leu160 residues further narrow the pocket.(26)
    However, rhodesain is 50% less reactive with a P2 β-branched valine and is completely nonreactive with a P2 arginine because of the presence of an alanine residue at the bottom of the S2 subsite, which is unable to interact with the latter amino acid.(34) However, it is important to clarify that the P2 residue alone is insufficient to influence the binding with the target enzyme because different interactions with other subsites are involved, such as the polar interactions between the peptide backbone and the Gln19, Gly66, Asp161, His162, and Trp184 residues of the target enzyme.
    A superimposition of the rhodesain–12a and rhodesain–12b complexes also highlights the rhodesain preferences at the P3 site. Although the protease is unable to form specific polar interactions with Mu (Mu = morpholine urea, i.e., 12b), this moiety is slightly preferred compared to the larger N-Mpip (N-Mpip = N-methylpiperazine, i.e., 12a).
    A recent comparative study(26) of the vinyl sulfones Mu-Leu-HPhe-SO2Ph (12c, K11017) (Figure 5) and 12a reported slightly enhanced activity for 12c compared to 12a, as demonstrated by the second-order rate inhibition constant values (12ak2nd = 9.00 × 106 M–1·min–1; 12ck2nd = 15.84 × 106 M–1·min–1).
    Because both vinyl sulfones contain bulky hydrophobic groups (Phe or Leu) at the P2 site for which rhodesain exhibits an equal preference, additional interactions with other subsites are hypothesized to explain the minor difference in potency. The morpholine group at the P3 position might create a network of bridging water molecules that anchor the morpholine oxygen of the inhibitor to the polar residues in the S3 site. The absence of these interactions in 12a, which contains a N-methylpiperazine nucleus, might explain its slightly reduced reactivity. Nevertheless, compound 12a displayed a notable submicromolar ED50 against the bloodstream form of T. brucei (ED50 = 0.9 μM), which prompted its selection as a preclinical therapeutic candidate.
    A series of 12a derivatives have been developed that contain different substituents at the P2 site and different groups of limited basicity at the P3 site.(43) The introduction of a methyl substituent in the meta or para position of the Phe aromatic ring produces a strong improvement in k2nd compared to model compound 12a (Table 04), which is likely attributable to the additional hydrophobic interactions between the methyl group and the hydrophobic environment of the binding site.
    Replacement of the N-methylpiperazine ring with aromatic nuclei at the P3 position further increased k2nd (e.g., 13b versus 13d).
    Table 4. Inhibition of Rhodesain and Cruzain by Modified Vinyl Sulfones at the P2 and P3 Positions

    Linear range. DHBD: 2,3-dihydro-1,4-benzodioxin-6-yl.

    The substituent at the P3 position (R′) also appears to affect the pharmacokinetic properties of the inhibitors, particularly oral bioavailability. In fact, while derivative 12b, which contains a morpholine nucleus, exhibited low oral bioavailability (3%), its N-methylpiperazine analogue (12a) exhibited increased oral bioavailability (19.9%), possibly due to its increased solubility in intestinal fluids.(44)
    The presence of the piperazine ring at the P3 position has been associated with inhibitor hepatotoxicity. However, such a moiety might allow the drug to accumulate within acidic compartments(45) (lysosomotropism), which might be a desired property when the parasitic targets are confined within these subcellular structures, as in the case of rhodesain.
    Derivative 12a has previously been the subject of preclinical investigations for the treatment of Chagas disease; interestingly, it displayed an acceptable pharmacokinetic profile, was nonmutagenic, and was safe in rodents, dogs, and primates.(46) This compound has now progressed into IND (Investigational New Drug) enabling studies in collaboration with the DNDi (Drugs for Neglected Diseases initiative). Indeed, on the basis of these results, the first phase 1 clinical trial will be conducted to assess safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics in healthy patient volunteers. The outcome of this clinical investigation will likely expedite progression to preclinical and clinical assessments for the treatment of HAT.
    Another group of Michael acceptor based peptidyl rhodesain inhibitors are fumaric acid derived peptides that were identified by a high-throughput screening approach (Figure 7).(47) Like the vinylsulfones, these peptides are typically characterized by the presence of hydrophobic amino acids (Leu, Ile, Phe, Chg, Phg) at the P2 position. Moreover, the introduction of unnatural amino acids (i.e., cyclohexylglycine, Chg, or phenylglycine, Phg) was explored as a method of increasing stability against proteolysis.
    Nonpolar amino acids were used at the P3 position, whereas the P4, P3′, P2′, and P1′ sites were generally kept constant. The pharmacophore portion of these peptides, which is represented by the central fumarate core, reacts through nucleophilic attack by the catalytic cysteine via a Michael type reaction; depending on the carbon attacked by the Cys25, the binding is shifted in the P- or P′-direction.
    Among the developed fumaric acid derivatives, a panel of submicromolar rhodesain inhibitors 14 has been identified (Table 5) in which the most active compounds (e.g., 14c–e) contain a Gln or Asn moiety at the P1 site, an unnatural amino acid at the P2 site (i.e., Chg), and a Val residue at the P3 site.
    To assess selectivity against the target enzyme, the most active fumaric-derived peptides were tested against cathepsins B and L, papain-family human cysteine proteases. These compounds exhibited optimal selectivity indices, with the exception of 14c. Unfortunately, the most potent rhodesain inhibitors, 14c and 14e, proved to be inactive when tested against T. b. brucei. Machon et al.(47) attributed the lack of trypanocidal activity to peptide instability under the conditions employed in the assay or to the inability of the peptides to cross the parasitic membrane.
    Table 5. Rhodesain and Cathepsins B and L Inhibitory and Trypanocidal Activities of Peptides 14a–da

    Starting from the fumaric acid heptapeptide library, a new series of cysteine protease inhibitors was developed bearing the above-described amino acid substituents with modified Michael systems (crotonic and acrylic acid derivatives, E and Z vinylogous amino acids, fumaric acid diesters, and fumaric and maleic acid amides).(48) The outcome of the initial screening, which was conducted using the synthesized cysteine protease inhibitors, was the identification of several potent rhodesain inhibitors, such as derivative 15 (Figure 8).
    The E-configured, N-trityl-protected (S)-Gln derivative 15a and (R)-Gln derivative 15b exhibited optimal inhibitory activity against both rhodesain (Ki of 0.47 and 0.14 μM, respectively, Table 6) and T. b. brucei (IC50 = 31.0 μM for 15a and IC50 = 3.5 μM for 15b). Unexpectedly, the (R) diastereoisomer 15b exhibited greater activity. The inhibition of rhodesain elicited by the (S/R)-Gln(Trt)-Phg derivatives was competitive and time-dependent.
    The trans fumaric acid amide 15c exhibited a Ki toward rhodesain in the micromolar range (7.6 μM) but displayed the highest antitrypanosomal activity (IC50 = 0.25 μM).
    Compound 15d and its Z-isomer 15e exhibited approximately equivalent activity against the target enzyme. However, when tested against T. b. brucei, 15d was found to be inactive whereas 15e exhibited IC50 = 2.9 μM. Both 15d and 15e behaved as time-independent and competitive inhibitors.
    Cytotoxicity assays performed with the J774.1 macrophage-like cell line for 15b, 15c, and 15e revealed a selectivity index (IC50(J774.1)/IC50(T. b. brucei)) in the 11–17 range, with slightly reduced toxicity for the promising, Gln(Trt)-containing compound 15b.

    3.1.3 Peptidyl Inhibitors with Other Types of Warheads

    Gonzalez et al.(51) developed the novel dipeptidyl-α,β-epoxy esters (2S,3S)-16b and (2R,3R)-16c (Table 7) by combining the reactivity of (2S,3S)-3-((S)-1-(isopentylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamoyl)oxirane-2-carboxylic acid (16a, E-64c)(49) (Table 7), a potent epoxysuccinyl-based cysteine protease inhibitor developed from the natural compound E-64,(49) and the dipeptide sequence CbzPhe-HPhe, which characteristically inhibits rhodesain(27) and cruzain.(50)
    Both diastereoisomers 16b and 16c exhibited potent inhibition of rhodesain and cruzain. Interestingly, compound 16c, which is characterized by the (2R,3R) configuration, which is opposite that of 16a, exhibited increased activity toward both enzymes relative to its (2S,3S) counterpart 14 (Table 7).
    Table 7. Structures of (2S,3S)-16b, (2R,3R)-16c, and 16a and Their Inhibitory Activities against Rhodesain and Cruzain
    Similar to epoxysuccinates, aziridine 2,3-dicarboxylates have been exploited to obtain irreversible cysteine protease inhibitors.(52) Representative analogues 17–22 (Table 8) exhibited Ki values against rhodesain in the submicromolar range. However, the antitrypanosomal activity of this class of inhibitors is modest, with IC50 values in the mid-micromolar range (Table 9).
    Table 8. Rhodesain Inhibitory and Trypanocidal Activities of Aziridine 2,3-Dicarboxylate Inhibitors 17–22a
    Table a

    nd, not determined.

    The aziridinyl peptides did not exhibit toxicity against macrophage-like J744-1 cells at concentrations up to 125 μM, with the exception of compounds 17 and 22, the cytotoxicity of which was comparable to that observed against T. b. brucei (see Table 8). The observed cytotoxicity was hypothesized to be strictly related to the peptide sequence and not the aziridine moiety. Further studies by Schirmeister et al. clarified that the inactivation of cysteine proteases can occur through aziridine ring-opening only if the 2,3-substituents are in the trans configuration.(53)
    Recently, azadipeptide nitriles were also identified as a promising class of papain-like cysteine protease inhibitors. Some of these compounds possess IC50 values against rhodesain in the low nanomolar/picomolar range.(54) In 2008, Gütschow et al. reported the first series of such cysteine protease inhibitors, which are capable of reacting with the Cys– anion of the active site to form a reversible isothiosemicarbazide adduct (Figure 9).(55) Azadipeptides, which are obtained by the isoelectric replacement of the Cα group with a nitrogen atom at the P1 position, are potent cathepsin L, S, and K inhibitors, and because of the methylated P2–P1 peptide bond, they are stable against proteolysis.
    On the basis of these findings and the significant structural homology between cathepsin L and rhodesain, a new library of azadipeptide nitriles was developed.(54) The new derivatives were characterized by a common 2,3-dihydro-1,4-benzodioxin-6-yl substituent at the P3 position, a Phe, Val, or Leu residue at the P2 site (R2) based on the strong preference of rhodesain for hydrophobic residues in this position,(41, 42) and substituents of different sizes at the P1 site (R1).
    As expected, the compounds bearing a Phe or Leu residue at the P2 position (i.e., 23a–e and 23k–o, respectively) were more potent inhibitors than those bearing a Val (23f–j) moiety at the same position (Table 9).

    Similarly, a group of azadipeptide nitriles containing a benzyl carbamate (Cbz) at the P3 position, a benzyl group at the P2 position, and a methyl group at the P1 position proved to be potent rhodesain inhibitors, with IC50 values in the subnanomolar range. Some of these inhibitors were also tested for anti-trypanosomal activity and exhibited ED50 values in the micromolar range against the bloodstream forms of T. b. brucei and enhanced growth inhibitory activity against the procyclic forms (PCF) (Table 10).

    Interestingly, the class of azadipeptide nitriles displayed an optimal correlation between enzyme inhibition and antiparasitic activity, which might reflect effective penetration through the parasite membrane and enhanced stability of these peptides toward proteolysis, which is attributed to the presence of a N-methylated hydrazide bond. These potent inhibitors might be novel valuable agents for the treatment of HAT if their efficacy and low toxicity are confirmed in vivo in animal models.

    3.2 Peptidomimetic Rhodesain Inhibitors

    3.2.1 Peptidomimetics Containing a 1,4-Benzodiazepine Scaffold

    As reported in the previous section, a large number of peptide-based rhodesain inhibitors have been developed over the past 2 decades, many of which exhibited significant potency and efficient trypanocidal activity. However, there are many limitations to the clinical applicability of these peptides including the following: (i) rapid degradation under physiological conditions by endogenous proteases; (ii) low selectivity due to the flexibility that allows them to adopt various conformations; (iii) poor absorption through cell membranes and through the BBB (if required for activity in the CNS).
    For these reasons, the design of peptidomimetic drugs has emerged as an attractive area of medicinal chemistry research to improve both pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic drug properties. Pseudopeptides can be developed by replacing the peptide backbone with amide bond isosteres, incorporating unnatural amino acids, or locking a defined conformation of the peptide into a rigid scaffold to limit the conformational freedom of the peptide and to stabilize the bioactive conformation that facilitates binding to the target enzyme.(56)
    Over the past decade, our research group has been actively involved in the development of novel peptidomimetic cysteine protease inhibitors based on a 1,4 benzodiazepine scaffold as a β-turn mimetic. The β-turn is frequently proposed as the structural motif of the biologically active form of linear peptides,(57-60) and as reported in the literature, the benzodiazepine (BZD) nucleus is a perfect mimetic of a number of β-turn types.(61, 62) In addition, this nucleus has optimal oral bioavailability and tolerability, as widely demonstrated by the significant use of benzodiazepines as muscle relaxants, anxiolytics, hypnotics, and anticonvulsants.
    On the basis of the above-described biological and chemical properties, we selected the 1,4-BZD scaffold as a dipeptide mimic and functionalized the 5-position with a phenyl ring and the 3-position with a carbamoyl moiety spanning into the P3 region. The design of the pharmacophore portion was based on the existing literature on peptidyl inhibitors. Thus, a classical warhead such as an aldehyde was initially selected. However, the introduction of an aspartyl aldehyde building block(63) selectively directed the activity against FP-2 of P. falciparum, whereas the corresponding lipophilic thioacylal 26a and acylal 26b (Figure 11)(64) behaved as more selective rhodesain inhibitors (Ki values of 0.7 and 0.8 μM, respectively), consistent with the strong preference of rhodesain for bulky substituents at the P1 site.(27, 34, 35) The trypanocidal activity of the most active compound, 26a, was evaluated using the T. b. brucei laboratory strain TC 221, revealing an IC50 value of 14.2 μM and confirming its ability to cross the parasite cell membrane.
    To further investigate the structural requirements of this class of inhibitors, we also prepared the corresponding vinyl esters, which should irreversibly inactivate rhodesain via Michael addition.(65)
    To carefully study the structure–activity relationship, the P1 glycine was replaced with a leucine (i.e., 27) to determine whether a bulkier residue might increase binding. In addition, various substituents with different electronic properties (e.g., 28, 29), were introduced at the C-4′ of the phenyl substituent on the BDZ scaffold and on the fused benzene ring. Furthermore, the 4-chloro-2-trifluoromethylphenyl group, which is directly linked to the carbamoyl moiety, was replaced with other aromatic rings and (cyclo)alkyl groups to optimize the fit of the P3 pocket.(66)
    As shown in Table 11, all of the compounds inhibited rhodesain in an irreversible manner with the exception of derivatives 30 and 31, which were time-independent inhibitors. According to our recent studies on FP-2 inhibitors with similar structures,(67) the presence of different groups (e.g., 4-MeO-C6H4) linked to the carbamoyl moiety can induce an incorrect orientation of the warhead within the catalytic site, precluding the formation of the Michael adduct and consequently the irreversible inhibition of the enzyme.
    The time-dependent inhibitors 27–29 and 33 exhibited dissociation constants (Ki) in the submicromolar range, with k2nd values ranging from 3.46 × 104 to 2.20 × 105 M–1 min–1.
    Interestingly, appending a bulky hydrophobic nucleus (i.e., compound 32) to the serine hydroxyl group through a carbamoyl linkage significantly increased both the potency (k2nd = 4.62 × 106 M–1 min–1) and binding affinity (Ki = 2.6 nM). This result clearly indicates that the adamantyl nucleus is able to create strong hydrophobic interactions with the P3 pocket, which normally accommodates this portion of the pseudo-peptide, facilitating the correct orientation of the peptide backbone and the electrophilic moiety into the rhodesain-binding site.
    The selectivity of vinyl esters 27–33 against the target enzyme was estimated by testing the inhibitors against papain-family human cysteine proteases such as cathepsins B and L. In most cases, the compounds exhibited Ki values 1–2 orders of magnitude higher than those for rhodesain inhibition, with excellent selectivity exhibited by compound 32 (Ki = 2.6 nM versus Ki = 13.7 μM for cathepsin B and Ki = 65.0 μM for cathepsin L).
    The best candidate, 32, was evaluated for its trypanocidal activity against T. b. brucei. Its IC50 value (4.8 μM), which is slightly better than that reported for eflornithine (IC50 = 22.9 μM),(52) clearly emphasizes the ability of our lead compound to cross parasite cell membranes and reach the target enzyme due to its significantly lipophilic profile.

    3.2.2 Peptidomimetic Vinyl Sulfones Containing a 10- to 11-Membered Ring Scaffold

    A careful analysis of the crystal structure of cruzain in complex with the peptidyl vinyl sulfone 12b (PDB code 1F2C(68)) led to the design of vinyl sulfones containing a 10- to 11-membered ring scaffold (Figure 12).(69) In these molecules, the geometry of the peptide backbone and the main hydrogen-bonding interactions were strictly maintained. The distance between the urea carbonyl and the γ-carbon of the P1 HPhe in 12b bound to cruzain is 4.51 Å, and these portions of the peptide are not involved in key interactions with the target enzyme. Therefore, Chen et al. immobilized these portions into a 10- to 11-membered ring scaffold, the optimal ring size for maintaining the bioactive conformation.(69) The labile and unstable aminal unit, which could be obtained by removal of the urea carbonyl, was replaced by a α-aminoamide, and last, a Leu residue was introduced at the P2 position to extend the spectrum of activity to other Clan CA cysteine proteases (e.g., rhodesain), which generally possess the same preference for Leu and Phe, in contrast to cruzain, which prefers solely Phe.
    Peptidomimetics 34 and 35, when tested against rhodesain and cruzain, exhibited activity toward both enzymes in the micromolar range (Figure 12). The 11-membered macrocycle, which is more flexible than the 10-membered analogue, displayed a slightly increased inhibitory activity.
    Notably, a significant decrease in potency was observed with respect to the parent vinyl sulfone 12b. Additional studies should be carried out to determine whether the removal of the urea portion of the acyclic vinyl sulfone 12b, initially considered nonessential for target binding, might negatively affect the interactions with the rhodesain active site.(69)

    3.3 Nonpeptidyl Rhodesain Inhibitors

    Nonpeptidyl lead scaffolds for rhodesain inhibitors with potent trypanocidal activities against cultured parasites were recently identified. The nonpeptidyl inhibitors belong to different chemical classes, including acylhydrazides, ureas and thioureas, thiosemicarbazones, and triazine nitriles. These molecules were generally identified by virtual screening or high throughput screening approaches, followed by rational drug design based on molecular modeling studies. Interestingly, structure–activity relationship studies for these compounds revealed that the most active inhibitors have recurring substitution patterns.

    3.3.1 Urea and Aroyl Thiourea Derivatives

    One of the first studies on nonpeptidyl rhodesain inhibitors was published by Du et al. in 2000.(70) In this work, noncovalent and reversible small molecule inhibitors of cruzain and rhodesain were developed by exploiting computational methods.(71, 72) This work identified ureas and aroyl thioureas as privileged structures, with several compounds exhibiting IC50 values lower than 10 μM against cruzain and rhodesain (Figure 13). The common structural feature of these inhibitors is the presence of two aromatic rings connected by a suitable spacer that establishes several H-bonding interactions with the binding pocket.
    Interestingly, these scaffolds are easily synthetically accessible and are suitable for a combinatorial chemistry approach. Moreover, these compounds generally possess druglike properties. When comparable substituents are considered, compounds containing the urea scaffold exhibit lower molecular weights than those with the aroyl thiourea group, despite sharing similar hydrogen bond donating and accepting capabilities. Although the cLogP of the urea scaffold is 0.3 units higher than the aroyl thiourea scaffold, it can be reduced by the addition of polar groups or groups such as pyridine or morpholine, resulting in increased aqueous solubility due to the formation of the corresponding salt.
    Interestingly, several of the compounds (37, 38, and 43) (Figure 13) contained a phenyl group connected with a five-membered heteroaromatic ring at one side of the urea/thiourea. Modeling studies indicated that the six–five combination of the aromatic rings (e.g., compounds 36–38) might exhibit enhanced interaction with the S2 pocket compared to a single six-membered ring. This combination is also present in compound 43, which was subsequently synthesized. This derivative also has a benzyloxy group on the other end of the molecule, which might result in an enhanced fit of the S1′ pocket. Compound 43 exhibited IC50 values of 3 and 3.5 μM against cruzain and rhodesain, respectively. Finally, a representative set of inhibitors bearing the urea and aroyl thiourea scaffolds (compounds 36, 37, 40, and 41) was selected to evaluate their selectivity against a panel of enzymes. These inhibitors exhibited optimal selectivity (Table 12) for cruzain and rhodesain over papain and cathepsin B within the papain family. Moreover, they did not inhibit trypsin, a serine protease. These inhibitors were established as reversible inhibitors because no decrease in enzyme activity was observed in a time-dependent inhibition study. Moreover, the percentage of enzyme inhibition was reduced when the substrate concentration was increased.
    Table 12. Activity and Selectivity of Selected Urea and Aroyl Thiourea Derivatives
     IC50 (μM)
    compdrhodesaincruzainpapaincathepsin Btrypsin
    363.03.1>5011>50
    372.01.2>5010.8>50

    Interestingly, some of these compounds exhibited activity in a cell culture assay of T. cruzi infection. In particular, infected mammalian cells treated with compound 36 survived 22 days, and those treated with compound 43 survived 18 days, whereas untreated cells survived only 6 days.(70) Unfortunately, data on T. brucei infected cells are unavailable.
    Medicinal chemistry efforts should be directed toward the optimization of these inhibitors to further enhance their inhibitory activities and selectivity for rhodesain. On the basis of computational studies, all of the inhibitors are proposed to interact only with the S2 and S1′ pockets, and thus, the affinity and specificity for the target enzyme might be rationally improved by further increasing the molecular complexity and adding additional fragments and substituents that can interact with accessory subsites, including the S3 pocket.

    3.3.2 Thiosemicarbazones

    Thiosemicarbazones are a class of small molecules that have been evaluated over the past 50 years as antiviral(73, 74) and anticancer(75) agents as well as antiparasitic compounds against P. falciparum(76) and T. cruzi.(77) The scaffold has the following advantageous properties: low molecular weight, reasonable cLogP, efficient hydrogen bond donating and accepting capabilities, and easy, economical synthetic processing. In 2002, Du et al. identified thiosemicarbazone as a common scaffold that is present in several cruzain inhibitors.(78) According to previous molecular modeling studies, thiosemicarbazones were proposed to inhibit cruzain through the formation of a reversible tetrahedral adduct via an attack of the thiolate anion on the carbon of the C═S.(78)
    A second generation of thiosemicarbazones was reported in 2004 by Greenbaum et al.(79) This series of compounds was designed to explore the substituents around the aromatic ring as well as N1-monosubstitution of the thiosemicarbazone scaffold to optimize the interaction with the S2 pocket. Moreover, some N1-disubstituted derivatives were synthesized to evaluate the interactions at the S1′ or S2′ pockets. Compounds with substituents at the 3′ (44a–e) and 4′ (45a–c) positions were effective rhodesain inhibitors in the mid-nanomolar to low micromolar range (Figure 14, Table 13), a result that is consistent with those obtained for cruzain, although notably, the arylamine derivatives 44b and 45b were inactive against cruzain.
    For many of these compounds, enzymatic activity corresponded with in vitro activity against cultured T. brucei (Table 13), indicating that the inhibition of rhodesain might be the primary mechanism of action of these derivatives. By contrast, the most potent compound against T. brucei (46) did not inhibit the enzyme but rather exhibited potential metal chelator activity. Compound 46 might kill T. brucei via a protease-independent mechanism or via the inhibition of another cysteine protease. Although none of the N1-disubstituted compounds (compounds 47a–c) exhibited significant inhibition of rhodesain, they all displayed optimal activity against T. brucei, which might be explained by increased uptake of the compound across the cell membranes. However, concomitant activity on other target proteins cannot be excluded.

    Some compounds (e.g., 45b, 46, and 47b) were tested for general toxicity in mice, and no toxicity was observed after 62 h. In addition to a lack of obvious toxicity, these scaffolds are nonpeptidic and achiral and require synthetic procedures that are relatively inexpensive and amenable to generating a chemical library. Therefore, these compounds might represent lead compounds for the generation of new antiparasitic agents based on a thiosemicarbazone scaffold.
    The structure–activity relationship of thiosemicarbazones was further characterized by Fujii et al. in 2005.(80) The authors explored modifications of the ethyl side chain of the model compound 48a and tested the new series against rhodesain and T. brucei (Figure 15).(80) Most of the compounds were more potent inhibitors of rhodesain than the lead compound 48a. Notably, both the n-butyl and bulkier arylalkyl substituent groups exhibited the same level of potency, whereas bulkier alkyl substituents (tert-butyl and cyclohexyl groups, compounds 48c,d) drastically reduced the potency. Interestingly, a number of the compounds exhibited potent activity against T. brucei.
    Subsequently, the study of thiosemicarbazones was extended, and substitution at the R1 and R positions (Table 14) by a variety of aryl moieties was evaluated.(81)

    The compounds reported in Table 14 exhibited submicromolar potency against rhodesain and micromolar trypanocidal activity. Regression analysis conducted on the series of compounds revealed only a weak positive association between the inhibition of rhodesain and trypanocidal activity (R2 = 0.3). The authors of that study used a parallel artificial membrane permeability assay (PAMPA) to determine that this series of thiosemicarbazone inhibitors generally exhibited similar permeabilities. Thus, differences in intracellular accumulation are not responsible for the low correlation between protease inhibition and trypanocidal activity.
    Significant specificity was not observed for the parasitic proteases relative to the human cathepsins. However, a significant degree of specificity was observed for the two cathepsin L-like enzymes (cathepsin L and rhodesain) compared to the two cathepsin B-like enzymes (cathepsin B and TbCatB). Moreover, the compounds in this series generally killed the parasites with significant selectivity relative to mammalian cells.
    Although the mechanism of action of these compounds is still not fully understood and there is insufficient published data supporting the contention that trypanocidal activity is directly correlated with rhodesain inhibition, the low cytotoxicity and optimal membrane permeability of the thiosemicarbazones suggest that they warrant further investigation as therapeutic agents for HAT.

    3.3.3 Natural Product Derivatives

    Natural product derivatives, such as derivatives of isatin and allicin, have been shown to inhibit rhodesain and to elicit antiprotozoal activity.
    1H-Indole-2,3-dione (50, isatin, Figure 16) is a natural product found in many plants, such as Isatis tinctoria, Calanthe discolor, and Couroupita guianensis.(82) Various derivatives of 50 inhibit cysteine and serine proteases and possess different pharmacological properties, including antiprotozoal activities.(83, 84)
    Chiyanzu et al.(85) exploited the ketone functionality of 50 to obtain the corresponding thiosemicarbazones as potential inhibitors of cruzain, rhodesain, and FP-2. Moreover, the authors investigated the activity of N-substituted isatins against the same enzymes (Figure 16).
    Whereas 50 was inactive against all of the tested enzymes, the corresponding thiosemicarbazones displayed modest activity against the three cysteine proteases. The compounds that exhibited the greatest rhodesain inhibitory activity were 51a and 51f, with IC50 values of 3.5 and 1 μM, respectively. Although the N-substituted isatins 52a and 52b exhibited only moderate activity against rhodesain (IC50 of 15 and 30 μM, respectively), they were nonetheless selective for rhodesain over cruzain and FP-2. Notably, isatin and its analogues act on a large number of biological targets and have a wide variety of potential pharmacological actions.
    S-Allyl-2-propenyl thiosulfinate (53, allicin, Figure 17), the main biologically active component of garlic extracts, is a natural compound with antioxidant properties that has been shown to have antiparasitic activity.(86-88) On the basis of NMR studies, its mechanism of action was elucidated in 1998.(89) It was speculated that 53 would react with the thiol groups of proteins, a hypothesis that was confirmed when 53 reacted with l-cysteine. The resulting product was S-allylmercaptocysteine, a compound in which the cysteine residue is blocked as a disulfide (Figure 17). Moreover, allicin was shown to irreversibly inhibit papain, the activity of which could be restored by treatment with glutathione, indicating that the inhibition was caused by the modification of a SH group in the enzyme by a thiol–disulfide exchange reaction.(89)
    On the basis of these data, 53 and specific symmetrical and asymmetrical derivatives (Figure 18) were tested against various cysteine proteases such as FP-2, rhodesain, and cathepsins B and L.(90) In addition, allyl disulfide (60) was tested, and no decrease in enzymatic activity was observed at 20 μM, indicating that the enzymatic inhibition is strictly related to the presence of the thiosulfinate moiety.
    The allicin derivatives shown in Figure 18 inhibited the selected proteases in the low micromolar range, with the exception of compounds 56 and 57 and the mixed thiosulfinate 61 (Table 15). The inactivity or weak activity of these compounds indicates that the reaction might be sterically hindered in the presence of a secondary (compound 57) or tertiary (compounds 56 and 61) carbon atom proximal to the sulfur atom of the thiosulfinate moiety, which is attacked by the Cys– anion of the active site. The most active inhibitors were allicin itself and derivatives 58 and 59; the last two derivatives bear large lipophilic groups that could fit the hydrophobic S2 pockets of the enzymes. No selectivity between the tested enzymes was observed.

    The compounds were also tested against cultured P. falciparum and T. b. brucei, and optimal antiplasmodial and antitrypanosomal activities were exhibited by compounds 53 and 59. However, in this series of derivatives, no clear correlation between antiprotease and antiparasitic activity was observed, possibly because these compounds might also target other proteases (e.g., FP-3 and TbCatB) or non-protease thiol-dependent enzymes (e.g., dehydrogenases). In addition, these compounds might elicit other mechanism of actions, including the rapid induction of cellular ROS formation, which has been implicated in DADS- and DATS-induced cancer cell apoptosis. Moreover, the cell permeability of the compounds might influence their antiparasitic activity.
    Because several plants that are traditionally used to treat malaria contain alkaloids with an isoquinoline core that exhibit broad-spectrum antimicrobial activities and other pharmacological effects,(91, 92) synthetic derivatives containing an isoquinoline core (e.g., the derivatives of the general structure of 62 (Figure 19)) have been reported.(93) These compounds were designed on the basis of homology modeling studies and inhibited FP-2 at micromolar concentrations. On the basis of these results, we recently examined a new series of variously decorated isoquinolines that were synthesized and tested against FP-2 as well as rhodesain.(94) Of these isoquinolines, three derivatives 63a, 63b, and 64 exhibited IC50 values of <10 μM against rhodesain. However, this new class of rhodesain inhibitors does not show selectivity with respect to human cathepsins.

    3.3.4 Triazine Nitriles

    A few years ago, an extensive high-throughput screen performed on 197 861 small molecules resulted in the identification of triazine nitriles, which are known inhibitors of other cysteine proteases, as reversible, competitive inhibitors of cruzain.(95) Because the triazine ring behaves as a strongly electron-withdrawing group, the nitrile moiety in this class of compounds is particularly electrophilic and is thought to form a covalent but reversible bond with the active site Cys in proteases. More recently, a structure–activity relationship study was performed on this triazine nitrile scaffold that yielded new compounds that were 350-fold more potent inhibitors of cruzain and rhodesain than the reference compounds 65 and 66 (Figure 20).(96)
    After initial optimization by varying the R1 substituent on the phenyl group to increase the chemical diversity, the triazine core was modified to adopt structural rigidity by incorporating one of the distal nitrogens into a heterocyclic ring, forming a purine core that was further decorated (Figure 20). With the exception of the reference compound 66, which is selective for cruzain, the other compounds exhibited similar inhibitory properties against rhodesain and cruzain. This is not surprising, given the structural homology of the two enzymes. Moreover, compounds 67f, 67j, 68, and 69a also exhibited low micromolar IC50 values against TbCatB and thus could be used to achieve a dual inhibition of both enzymes, potentially representing a multitargeted approach for blocking different parasitic life-cycle stages.

    The compounds were also tested against T. brucei (Table 16). As shown in Table 16, several new triazines (67c,d, 67j, 68) exhibited activity against T. brucei, with MIC50 values of 6 μM (the MIC50 is the lowest tested compound concentration that inhibits parasite growth by at least 50%), in contrast to lead compounds 65 and 66, which exhibited no trypanocidal activity at concentrations up to 100 μM. Unfortunately, these analogues were also active against a limited number of cathepsins that have significant homology with human papain cysteine proteases.
    Another series of triazine nitriles was reported by Ehmke et al. in 2011.(97) On the basis of molecular modeling studies, a diamino-substituted triazine was identified as a suitable central scaffold for positioning moieties in the S1, S2, and S3 binding pockets and for directing the thioimidate adduct into the stabilizing oxyanion hole (Figure 21). Therefore, a series of functionalized triazine nitriles was synthesized by varying the S1, S2, and S3 substituents (Table 17).
    The compounds were tested against rhodesain and FP-2. Of this series, compounds 70 and 71 displayed the highest affinities for rhodesain, with Ki values of 2 and 8 nM, respectively. Compound 70 was demonstrated to be a competitive inhibitor, and its behavior can presumably be assigned to the whole series (Figure 22, Table 17).
    In general, the activities of the tested compounds against rhodesain and FP-2 were quite similar. However, the 2-adamantyl-substituted triazines 72 and 73 were moderately active against FP-2 but completely inactive against rhodesain, suggesting the presence of a less extended S2 pocket within the latter enzyme. Most importantly, the two enzymes differ at the bottom of this pocket. In fact, FP-2 exhibits a strong preference for the unsubstituted cyclohexyl moiety (i.e., compound 71) over the 4-substituted moiety (i.e., compound 70), whereas both 70 and 71 exhibited Ki values in the nanomolar range when tested against rhodesain. These results can be explained by molecular modeling studies indicating that the bottom of the pocket in FP-2 is narrower and more polar than that in rhodesain.

    To evaluate the general selectivity of these compounds, these triazine nitrile derivatives were tested against other related cysteine proteases. Only compounds 71, 74, 75, and 76 exhibited affinity for human cathepsin L in the low nanomolar range, whereas all of the compounds were highly selective against human cathepsin B. Furthermore, all of the compounds were inactive against α-chymotrypsin, reflecting selectivity for cysteine over serine proteases.
    Finally, the compounds were tested in vitro against P. falciparum and T. b. rhodesiense (Table 17). The IC50 values against T. b. rhodesiense ranged from 15.0 to 44.1 μM. Comparable data were obtained from assays against T. b. brucei. A correlation between the inhibition of the parasitic proteases and in vitro activity could not be established, possibly because of off-target effects or the physical chemical properties of the compounds.

    3.3.5 Guanidinofuran and Guanidinopyrrole Derivatives

    A new class of non-peptide rhodesain inhibitors was recently reported by Langolf et al.(98) During a general protease- and cell-based screen using different proteases, the authors discovered hybrid compounds that were originally designed as aspartic protease inhibitors. These compounds contained both peptidic and nonpeptidic moieties for potent, reversible inhibition of falcipains that exhibited antiplasmodial activity. To identify the fragment responsible for the activity, the two building blocks, the peptidic and the nonpeptidic portions, were tested separately. Unexpectedly, both fragments were efficient FP-2 inhibitors, and therefore, a structure–activity relationship study of the non-peptide fragment was performed in which 21 derivatives were synthesized and tested against FP-2 and rhodesain. Representative compounds exhibiting inhibitory activity against rhodesain are shown in Table 18. Within this series, the pyrrole core fragment was also bioisosterically replaced by furan.
    The most active inhibitor against rhodesain was the para-substituted aniline derivative 78 (Ki = 28 nM, Table 18), although all of the other compounds also displayed favorable inhibition of this enzyme, with Ki values ranging from 50 nM (79) to 5.29 μM (80) (Table 18). In contrast to the pyrrole derivative 83, which exhibited a significantly low Ki value (50 nM), the furan analogue 82 was 40-fold less active against rhodesain (Ki = 2.08 μM). For all of the other compounds, marginal differences were detected between the pyrrole- and furan-based compounds. Moreover, the substituents at different positions (ortho, meta, or para) of the aniline moiety, as well as the connection to the furan or pyrrole rings via aromatic or benzylic amino groups, appeared to marginally affect both antiparasitic and enzymatic activities.
    The inhibitors exhibited IC50 values against T. b. brucei between 0.22 and 9.17 μM (81 and 83, respectively). All of the compounds exhibited only weak or moderate cytotoxicity against mammalian cells (from 19.0 μM for 81 to >100 μM in most cases).
    Table 18. Inhibition of Rhodesain and FP-2 by Guanidinofuran and Guanidinopyrrole Derivatives and in Vitro Activity against T. b. brucei
    The active compounds were predominantly nonpolar and thus fit nicely into the nonpolar binding pocket of the enzyme. Compound 77 was selected as the representative inhibitor for calculations using Autodock. It contains two aromatic, planar moieties on either side of the central heterocycle and is predicted to span approximately the entire substrate binding cleft and fit optimally into the groove between S2 and S1. On the basis of the complementary nonpolar nature of the binding pockets, the inhibitors should bind via hydrophobic and aromatic interactions. Moreover, hydrogen bonds are predicted to be important for binding. In this case, three hydrogen bonds should be formed between inhibitor 77 and the Gln19, Cys25, and Gly66 residues. The modeling study also suggests that the inhibitors could be further improved by addressing the S3 and S1′ sites, which are not occupied by this series of inhibitors.

    4 Conclusion and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Proteases are ubiquitous in all life forms and are essential to many organisms because they regulate a number of cellular processes by catalyzing the enzymatic degradation of proteins. Whereas serine proteases are predominant in mammals, parasitic organisms commonly rely on cysteine proteases of the clan CA family throughout their life cycles. Thus, clan CA cysteine proteases are regarded as promising targets for the design of selective antiparasitic drugs with low toxicity against human cells. In this regard, rhodesain, the major cathepsin L-like cysteine protease of T. b. rhodesiense, which is the causative agent of sleeping sickness in East and Southern Africa, has been proposed as a promising therapeutic target for the development of novel antitrypanosomal agents with an innovative mechanism of action. Selectivity over human cathepsins, particularly cathepsin L, is the first important issue that needs to be addressed. Selectivity can be achieved by exploiting the differences in the enzyme subsites, notably by inserting appropriate substituents at the P2, P3, and P1′ sites. Moreover, reversible inhibitors might offer the potential of fewer off-target side effects compared to irreversible inhibitors, although the latter might represent more effective trypanocidal agents because of the stable inactivation of the target enzyme.
    In general, submicromolar activity against the bloodstream form of T. brucei and a high selectivity index with respect to human cells are required to select a candidate for entering preclinical animal studies. In this regard, the most promising peptidyl inhibitors belong to the classes of vinyl sulfones, aldehydes, and diazomethylketones. In addition, azadipeptide nitriles appear to exhibit potent activity, although in vivo efficacy and toxicity studies have not yet been performed.
    Vinyl sulfones are also considered promising drug candidates because of their properties, including (i) selectivity for cysteine proteases over serine-, aspartyl-, and metalloproteases, (ii) stable inactivation of the target enzyme, (iii) nonreactivity in the absence of the target protease,(40) (iv) safety profiles in cavies and primates,(2, 99) (v) an acceptable pharmacokinetic profile.
    In addition to 12a, other promising agents are represented by the peptidyl aldehydes 10a and 10b and the diazomethyl ketone 10c, which exhibit potent activity against the enzyme and have been proven to inhibit trypanosome proliferation in the blood with ED50 values in the nanomolar range. A favorable combination of enzymatic activity and trypanocidal profile was observed for the peptide 10b (ED50 = 18 nM), which also exhibited an optimal selectivity index (HL-60/T. b. brucei = 1150). Thus, peptide 10b appears as an optimal candidate for development in preclinical studies in animal models of African trypanosomiasis.
    Among azadipeptide nitriles, several subnanomolar rhodesain inhibitors endowed with micromolar trypanocidal activity have been developed. An attractive feature of this class of molecules compared to other peptidic derivatives is the stability that they exhibit toward proteolysis, which is conferred by the presence of an N-methylated hydrazide bond.
    The chemical stability and enzymatic stability of the developed inhibitors are indeed important issues, particularly considering that orally administrable drugs are highly desirable treatments for neglected diseases. Thus, the development of alternative peptidomimetic or small molecule inhibitors represents an attractive area of research.
    Among nonpeptidyl inhibitors, some of the thiosemicarbazones that were developed by Mallari et al.(80, 81) (e.g., 48b, 48e) showed activity in the nanomolar range against both rhodesain and T. b. brucei and exhibited an optimal correlation between enzymatic inhibition and trypanocidal activity. Nonpeptidic inhibitors might generally represent preferred therapeutic modalities due to their more favorable pharmacokinetic profiles, which are a consequence of their enhanced physicochemical properties and increased stability.
    Another important aspect that must be considered when selecting a new class of nonpeptidic inhibitors for development into potential antiparasitic agents is the synthetic feasibility of the scaffold, which might include the use of cheap reagents, the absence of stereogenic centers, and the suitability for a combinatorial chemistry approach, which facilitates the generation of a library.
    As noted throughout this Perspective, a central issue that might arise when developing new rhodesain inhibitors as antitrypanosomal agents is the absence of an ideal correlation between enzymatic inhibitory and antitrypanosomal activities. A typical example is the case of fumarates, where submicromolar inhibitors of rhodesain did not exhibit any activity against cultured T. brucei. However, this phenomenon is not unusual during the development of antiparasitic agents. A typical problem that can limit antiparasitic activity, despite efficient inhibition of the target protein, is the inability to cross the parasite membrane. The selection of appropriate substituents for the P3 site has been proposed as a strategy to increase the penetration of parasitic membranes.
    In the case of peptidyl inhibitors, another reason for the lack of correlation between enzymatic and cellular activity might be the proteolytic instability of the inhibitor molecule, which can be increased, for instance, by inserting d-amino acids into the peptide scaffold or, as mentioned for azadipeptide nitriles, by methylating the amide bond.
    Prodrug approaches, notably the design of suitable carrier-linked prodrugs directed to nutrient transporters, have been proposed as a tool for increasing the intracellular uptake of inhibitors and might represent a reasonable option when potent and selective enzymatic inhibitors fail to elicit antitrypanosomal effects.(100)
    Finally, emerging technologies such as the incorporation of drugs into liposomes or nanocarriers might offer new opportunities for developing potent enzymatic inhibitors into efficacious antitrypanosomal agents, as was recently performed in the field of antimalarial therapies.(101, 102)

      History of sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
      Cox Francis E G
      Infectious disease clinics of North America (2004), 18 (2), 231-45 ISSN:0891-5520.
      Infections with subspecies of the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei cause important wasting diseases in Africa (nagana in cattle and sleeping sickness in humans). These diseases were little known until the end of the nineteenth century when serious epidemics of nagana were reported and raised concern among the colonial powers. The early history of sleeping sickness revolves around the discovery of the causative organism, its mode of transmission,and its life cycle in the tsetse fly. The history continues into the twentieth century with the discovery of how the parasites evade the immune response, frustrating the development of a vaccine; the failure to develop cheap and effective drugs; and the development of alternative approaches to control the tsetse fly vector.

      The trypanosomiases
      Barrett Michael P; Burchmore Richard J S; Stich August; Lazzari Julio O; Frasch Alberto Carlos; Cazzulo Juan Jose; Krishna Sanjeev
      Lancet (London, England) (2003), 362 (9394), 1469-80 ISSN:.
      The trypanosomiases consist of a group of important animal and human diseases caused by parasitic protozoa of the genus Trypanosoma. In sub-Saharan Africa, the final decade of the 20th century witnessed an alarming resurgence in sleeping sickness (human African trypanosomiasis). In South and Central America, Chagas' disease (American trypanosomiasis) remains one of the most prevalent infectious diseases. Arthropod vectors transmit African and American trypanosomiases, and disease containment through insect control programmes is an achievable goal. Chemotherapy is available for both diseases, but existing drugs are far from ideal. The trypanosomes are some of the earliest diverging members of the Eukaryotae and share several biochemical peculiarities that have stimulated research into new drug targets. However, differences in the ways in which trypanosome species interact with their hosts have frustrated efforts to design drugs effective against both species. Growth in recognition of these neglected diseases might result in progress towards control through increased funding for drug development and vector elimination.

      Antigenic variation in Trypanosoma brucei infections: an holistic view
      Turner, C. Michael R.
      Journal of Cell Science (1999), 112 (19), 3187-3192CODEN: JNCSAI; ISSN:0021-9533. (Company of Biologists Ltd.)
      A review with 52 refs. Trypanosoma brucei parasites undergo clonal phenotypic (antigenic) variation to promote their transmission between mammals and tsetse-fly vectors. This process is classically considered to be a mechanism for evading humoral immune responses, but such an explanation cannot account for the high rate of switching between variable antigens or for their hierarchical (i.e. non-random) expression. I suggest that these anomalies can be explained by a new model: that antigenic variation has evolved as a bifunctional, rather than as a unifunctional, strategy that not only evades humoral immune responses but also enables competition between parasite strains in concomitantly infected hosts. This competition causes a depression of cellular responses. My proposal gives rise to a no. of testable predictions. First, low nos. of trypanosomes should express some variable antigen types (VATs) in infections several weeks before these VATs are detectable. Second, as an infection progresses, the no. of VATs expressed simultaneously in the population should decrease. Third, immunization to generate a T helper 1 response against those VATs that are expressed most frequently should lower parasitemias and reduce virulence.

      Barry, J. D.; McCulloch, R. Antigenic variation in trypanosomes: enhanced phenotypic variation in a eukaryotic parasite Adv. Parasitol. 2001, 49, 1– 70
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Antigenic variation in trypanosomes: enhanced phenotypic variation in a eukaryotic parasite
      Barry J D; McCulloch R
      Advances in parasitology (2001), 49 (), 1-70 ISSN:0065-308X.
      African trypanosomes are unicellular, eukaryotic parasites that live extracellularly in a wide range of mammals, including humans. They have a surface coat, composed of variant surface glycoprotein (VSG), which probably is essential and acts as a defence against general innate immunity and against acquired immunity directed at invariant surface antigens. In effect, the VSG is the only antigen that the host can target, and each trypanosome expresses only one VSG. To counter specific antibodies against the VSG, trypanosomes periodically undergo antigenic variation, the change to expression of another VSG. Antigenic variation belongs to the general survival strategy of enhanced phenotypic variation, where a subset of 'contingency' genes of viruses, bacteria and parasites hypermutate, allowing rapid adaptation to hostile or changing environments. A fundamental feature of antigenic variation is its link with the population dynamics of trypanosomes within the single host. Antigenic variants appear hierarchically within the mammalian host, with a mixture of order and randomness. The underlying mechanisms of this are not understood, although differential VSG gene activation may play a prominent part. Trypanosome antigenic variation has evolved a second arm in which the infective metacyclic population in the tsetse fly expresses a defined mixture of VSGs, although again each trypanosome expresses a single VSG. Differential VSG expression enhances transmission to new hosts, in the case of bloodstream trypanosomes by prolonging infection, and in the metacyclic population by generating diversity that may counter existing partial immunity in reservoir hosts. Antigenic variation employs a huge repertoire of VSG genes. Only one is expressed at a time in bloodstream trypanosomes, as a result of transcription being restricted to a set of about 20 bloodstream expression sites (BESs), which are at chromosome telomeres. Only one BES is active at a time, probably through transcriptional elongation being inhibited in the silent BESs. Although transcriptional switching between BESs can effect a VSG switch, the most prolific switch route involves homologous recombination of deoxyribonucleic acid, usually by the copying of a silent gene into a BES. Hierarchical expression of VSGs may be dictated in part by the different types of locus occupied by VSG genes. The VSG genes expressed in the metacyclic population also occupy telomeric sites, which appear to be derived from BESs but have a simpler structure. Their differential expression is achieved by random transcriptional activation; the detailed story requires direct study of the metacyclic stage itself. Available evidence suggests that the VSG originated as a surface receptor, and it can be proposed that a number of selective events have contributed to the evolution of the complex, multisystem phenomenon that antigenic variation has become.
